item.title: Android Circuit: New Galaxy S10 Plus Leaks, Three New Nokia Handsets, OnePlus 5G Confirmed - Forbes
item.description:
Android Circuit: New Galaxy S10 Plus Leaks, Three New Nokia Handsets, OnePlus 5G Confirmed  Forbes

Taking a look back at seven days of news and headlines across the world of Android, this week’s Android Circuit includes no notch in the Galaxy S10, the 5G S10 confirmed for America, the OnePlus 5G heading to the UK, three new Nokia handsets, a review of the Pocophone F1, Huawei’s ongoing security issues, and an innovation award for the Pixel 3 and 3XL. Android Circuit is here to remind you of a few of the many things that have happened around Android in the last week (and you can find the weekly Apple news digest here). No Notch, But There Will Be A Hole, In The New Galaxy S10 Samsung appe...

item.title: China's Xiaomi takes lead over Apple as top seller of wearable technology globally - The Telegraph
item.description:
China's Xiaomi takes lead over Apple as top seller of wearable technology globally  The Telegraph

Chinese smartphone specialist Xiaomi has taken a lead over Apple as the world’s largest manufacturer of wearables, according to new figures from an industry analyst. A report from the International Data Corporation found that Xiaomi took top position in the third quarter of 2018 following positive sales of its Mi Band 3, a fitness tracker. Xiaomi’s push into markets such as India, Europe and the Middle East has been attributed to its overtaking of Apple. The share of the company’s deliveries within its home market has dropped from 80pc to 61pc as its international expansion plans pick up pa...

item.title: Oppo R17 Pro Review: The World's Fastest Charging Phone - Forbes
item.description:
Oppo R17 Pro Review: The World's Fastest Charging Phone  Forbes

The Oppo R17 Pro with its gorgeous gradient-colored back. Most Chinese smartphone brands nowadays pump out four, five, or six devices a year, to a market that’s already beyond saturate. Many of these manufacturers barely differentiate each of these handsets, so much so that they tend to get lost in the noise and are forgotten quickly. However Oppo, for the most part, has done a solid job of making sure each release is worth covering, with at least one head-turning feature. The Find X, for example, was an absolute stunner in design and craftsmanship and will likely end up in one of the top t...

item.title: Former YY CTO Gets $70 Million In US-China Deal For His New Voice Chat App From Xiaomi's VC Firm - Forbes
item.description:
Former YY CTO Gets $70 Million In US-China Deal For His New Voice Chat App From Xiaomi's VC Firm  Forbes

Live streaming with voice chat is taking off Photo credit: Getty U.S.-China trade winds are prominent in a recent $70 million cross-border investment in cloud communications company Agora.io in Santa Clara and Shanghai. New York hedge fund Coatue Management, an increasingly active tech investor in cutting-edge startups, led the deal along with SIG and China investors Morningside and Shunwei Capital. Tony Zhao, founder and CEO of Agora, brings China and U.S. experience to his latest startup from roles as former CTO of Chinese social media giant YY and founding engineer at WebEx Communicat...

item.title: Nokia 7.1 Review: King Of The Middle Of The Road - Forbes
item.description:
Nokia 7.1 Review: King Of The Middle Of The Road  Forbes

Not everyone wants a high-end flagship smartphone. Not everyone wants to pay the high cost to own one of these computational monsters outright or can budget for two years of contract payments. Even options such as the OnePlus 6T or the Xiaomi Mi8 Pro can be seen as overkill for people who just want ‘a decent smartphone’ to get them through the day. The rise in price of the flagship iPhone and Galaxy handsets have left a number of spaces between the high flyers and the ‘as low a price as you can go’ market. In here you will find the affordable flagships from the aforementioned OnePlus and X...

item.description:
Android Circuit: New Galaxy Details Leak, Nokia 9's Monster Camera, OnePlus 7 Fights OnePlus 5G  Forbes

Android Circuit is here to remind you of a few of the many things that have happened around Android in the last week (and you can find the weekly Apple news digest here). How Many Lenses? While the Galaxy S10 likely to make up the bulk of Samsungs’s high-end handset ...

item.title: OnePlus 6T Review: Competitors Have Caught Up In Value, But OnePlus Software Still King - Forbes
item.description:
OnePlus 6T Review: Competitors Have Caught Up In Value, But OnePlus Software Still King  Forbes

The OnePlus 6T has a 6.4-inch OLED display. The OnePlus 6T is the fifth phone from the upstart brand I’ve tested in a professional capacity, and this is the toughest one to judge. It’s not because the 6T isn’t good, or a step backwards. No, it’s the best OnePlus phone yet. But it’s trickier this time around because circumstances around the phone have changed. For years, OnePlus phones were undoubtedly the best value on the market. Other phones that ran on the same Snapdragon chipset almost always cost several hundred dollars more, and other phones in the mid-tier market were significantly l...

item.title: China's Xiaomi swings to net profit in third-quarter on robust sales in India, Europe - Reuters
item.description:
China's Xiaomi swings to net profit in third-quarter on robust sales in India, Europe  Reuters

Chinese smartphone maker Xiaomi Inc said on Monday it swung to a net profit in the third quarter, beating analyst estimates, driven by robust sales in India and Europe. Profit for the three months through September reached 2.48 billion yuan ($357.23 million), versus an 11 billion yuan loss in the same period a year earlier. That compared with a 1.92 billion yuan average of five analyst estimates compiled by Refinitiv Eikon. Xiaomi also said operating profit sank 38.4 percent to 3.59 billion yuan in the third quarter. Revenue rose 49.1 percent to 50.85 billion yuan. The mixed results come am...

item.title: Wednesday Tech Wrap: Facebook's Digital Worlds, Apple 'Prepping 3 iPhones,' Xiaomi's Mi 6 - Forbes Now
item.description:
Wednesday Tech Wrap: Facebook's Digital Worlds, Apple 'Prepping 3 iPhones,' Xiaomi's Mi 6  Forbes Now

SAN JOSE, CA – APRIL 18: Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg delivers the keynote address at Facebook’s F8 Developer Conference on April 18, 2017 at McEnery Convention Center in San Jose, California. The conference will explore Facebook’s new technology initiatives and products. (Photo by Justin Sullivan/Getty Images) Facebook has been holding its annual F8 conference this week and Mark Zuckerberg has been talking a great deal about virtual and augmented reality. During his keynote he unveiled AR Studio, an open source platform that developers so that Facebook’s mobile app can turn into a home for...

item.title: Xiaomi on comeback trail as smartphone sales soar - Financial Times
item.description:
Xiaomi on comeback trail as smartphone sales soar  Financial Times

Xiaomi, once the world’s most valuable unicorn, looked set to become one of China’s biggest unicorpses: it burnt cash, and stumbled with supply problems. Now, with fortunes improving, it is staging its next act: Chinese phoenix. The Beijing-based tech company, which makes products ranging from smartphones to smart rice cookers, re-entered the top five of global smartphone makers in the second quarter, as shipments surged 59 per cent year on year to 21m, according to the IDC research firm. The recovery, noted founder and chief executive Lei Jun, “follows a year of setbacks that collectively ...

item.title: Didi seeks $6 billion funding, to become China's second-most valuable private firm - Reuters
item.description:
Didi seeks $6 billion funding, to become China's second-most valuable private firm  Reuters

By Julie Zhu and Cate Cadell HONG KONG/BEIJING (Reuters) - Didi Chuxing, China's top ride-hailing firm, is set to become the country's second-most valuable privately owned company, with a valuation of more than $50 billion, through a fund raising round of up to $6 billion, sources said on Thursday. The valuation represents a jump from Didi's $34 billion price tag in August, when it agreed to acquire Uber Technology Inc's China business, and also puts it closer to the U.S. firm's $68 billion. It also propels Didi well above Xiaomi Inc, which held the title of China's most valuable startup af...

item.title: Fitbit losing major ground to Apple and Xiaomi - MarketWatch
item.description:
Fitbit losing major ground to Apple and Xiaomi  MarketWatch

By Jennifer Booton Fitbit’s shipments plunged 23% during the holiday while Xiaomi’s soared 96% and Apple notched its best quarter for wearables Getty Images Fitbit Inc. is barely hanging on to its position as the No. 1 wearable manufacturer in the world and could soon give up the title to Xiaomi or Apple. While Fitbit (FIT) reported an abysmal holiday shopping season that prompted the company to ax 110 jobs, new data show the rest of the wearables industry made out nicely. Worldwide shipments of wearables soared 17% in the fourth quarter to a record high, led by gains from China’s Xiaomi an...

item.title: Camera Shootout: Xiaomi Mi 6 Vs. Samsung Galaxy S8 - Forbes Now
item.description:
Camera Shootout: Xiaomi Mi 6 Vs. Samsung Galaxy S8  Forbes Now

The Xiaomi Mi 6 (left); Samsung Galaxy S8 (middle); and the Huawei Mate 9 Pro. In the past week I’ve been testing the newest flagships from Xiaomi and Samsung, and while they’re phones aimed at different markets — the Mi 6 won’t be released in North America and sells for roughly half of what the Galaxy S8 is going for — there are quite a bit of similarities between the two. For example, both phones use Snapdragon 835, the latest and much-hyped chip from Qualcomm (some versions of the S8 also runs on Samsung’s own Exynos 8895 chip); both phones come in all sleek black; and both are following...

item.title: Phonemakers pile in to exploit Samsung weakness - Reuters
item.description:
Phonemakers pile in to exploit Samsung weakness  Reuters

By Eric Auchard and Harro Ten Wolde BARCELONA (Reuters) - Phonemakers are piling in to fill a gap in the market left by Samsung (005930.KS: Quote, Profile, Research, Stock Buzz), still licking its wounds from a costly recall of its flagship Note 7 and with no key device of its own to launch at the telecom industry's biggest annual fair. China's Huawei [HWT.UL], the most likely contender to fill the hole in the premium end of the market, took the wraps off a new phone in its quest to displace Samsung as the world's no. 2 smartphone maker after Apple (AAPL.O: Quote, Profile, Research, Stock B...

item.title: Nubia X Review: Two Screens, Two Fingerprint Scanners, Too Weird? - Forbes
item.description:
Nubia X Review: Two Screens, Two Fingerprint Scanners, Too Weird?  Forbes

The Nubia X has a screen on the front and back of the phone. To what end will Chinese brands go to avoid needing a notch? Vivo designed a phone with a tiny pop-up camera module half a year ago. Then came Oppo with a phone whose entire forehead elevated up and down. And last month, Honor and Xiaomi each introduced slider phones just days apart. In between, there are smaller Shenzhen brands like Bluboo who experimented with a flip-over camera system. Nubia, however, may have come up with the most extreme idea yet. Its latest phone — a surprise release from a brand that was hit with a near dea...

item.title: Ofo, Chinese bike-sharing firm, raises $450 million in latest funding round - Reuters
item.description:
Ofo, Chinese bike-sharing firm, raises $450 million in latest funding round  Reuters

SHANGHAI/HONG KONG (Reuters) - Chinese bike-sharing start-up ofo said it has raised $450 million in a fresh round of funding, as the firm faces up against deep-pocketed rival Mobike in one of the hottest sectors to attract tech investors. Investment group DST Global, ride-hailing giant Didi Chuxing and CITIC's private equity arm were among investors, the company said in a statement. Ofo and Mobike are two of a growing number of bike-sharing services in China that allow users to find, unlock and pay to rent the bicycles through a smartphone app, targeting younger consumers tired of congested...

item.title: China’s tech groups dig deep for employee housing - Financial Times
item.description:
China’s tech groups dig deep for employee housing  Financial Times

China’s lofty property prices are prompting the country’s tech titans to revive old-school communist policies and help put a roof over their employees’ heads. While a few decades ago workers were housed in basic accommodation owned by the state, today some of China’s biggest private companies are doling out interest-free loans and subsidies to enable workers to buy their own homes. Alibaba and Tencent, two of the country’s internet trinity, are among those helping employees buy apartments. Tencent, the social media group headquartered in the southern boomtown of Shenzhen, offers interest-fr...

item.title: Xiaomi Follows In Footsteps Of Apple And Samsung With Its Own Smartphone Chip - Forbes Now
item.description:
Xiaomi Follows In Footsteps Of Apple And Samsung With Its Own Smartphone Chip  Forbes Now

Lei Jun, Chairman and CEO of Xiaomi, presents the new Surge S1 chipset at a launch event in Beijing on February 28, 2017 (Photo credit: NICOLAS ASFOURI/AFP/Getty Images) Once a darling of the global startup scene, Xiaomi has fallen from the number one spot in China’s fast-moving smartphone market. Now the Beijing-based phonemaker is following the examples of smartphone giants Apple, Samsung and Huawei by developing its own chip in hopes of reigniting growth. The company announced its first internally-developed chipset, dubbed the Surge S1, on Tuesday. The new chip will power the company’s l...

item.title: Xiaomi Redmi Note 4 becomes fastest-selling smartphone in India - The Independent
item.description:
Xiaomi Redmi Note 4 becomes fastest-selling smartphone in India  The Independent

Xiaomi says its new Redmi Note 4 has become the fastest selling smartphone in India. The Chinese firm said it had moved more than one million units in just 45 days since its launch, meaning one sold every four seconds. The phone is the successor to the Redmi Note 3, which shifted more than 2.3 million units in the country following its 2016 launch, making it the best-selling smartphone in India in terms of online sales. Read more - iPhone or Android? Bizarre new case makes dilemma seemingly redundant - Huawei P10: Smartphone aims to stand out in 'colour of the year' - 2017’s smartphone desi...

item.title: China smartphone maker Xiaomi designs its first chip - Financial Times
item.description:
China smartphone maker Xiaomi designs its first chip  Financial Times

China’s Xiaomi has become the world’s fourth smartphone maker to design its own processor, revealing its “Pinecone” chip on Tuesday aimed at breaking its reliance on foreign providers such as Qualcomm. The handset maker is leading a wave of Chinese tech groups that are trying to follow Apple, Samsung and Huawei by creating their own internal intellectual property, rather than relying on external sources. “The ability to create its own chip sets is the pinnacle of achievement for any smartphone company. For Xiaomi, the move is an essential next step in our development,” said Lei Jun, chief e...

item.title: Tax reform disrupts efforts to lift India’s domestic phone sector - Financial Times
item.description:
Tax reform disrupts efforts to lift India’s domestic phone sector  Financial Times

A string of Mandarin characters flashes across a blue-lit smartphone display panel at a factory in the north Indian technology hub of Noida, as an Intex Technologies technician tests its latest batch of Chinese supplies. In a larger, adjacent room, long lines of workers in protective white coats and caps are assembling phones from dozens of other components, from microphones to camera sensors, which again come mostly from China. This dependence has sparked condemnation of Intex and other Indian electronics groups, as critics argue that they have simply moved onshore the assembly of Chinese ...

item.title: As Apple slows, fast-moving Chinese rivals gain in wealthy markets - Reuters
item.description:
As Apple slows, fast-moving Chinese rivals gain in wealthy markets  Reuters

By Sijia Jiang and Jeremy Wagstaff HONG KONG/SINGAPORE (Reuters) - Slowing innovation at iPhone maker Apple gives Asian rivals their best chance yet to conquer developed markets, retailers and consumers say - thanks to better designs and lower prices. Apple last week unveiled new iPhones with wireless charging, an edge-to-edge screen and dual cameras - all features already widely available in phones from China's Huawei and Oppo, and Samsung Electronics. While Apple must convince buyers to fork out nearly $1,000 for its high-end model, challengers are tilting at the luxury market, offering s...

item.title: Nokia warns on challenging telecom market conditions - Financial Times
item.description:
Nokia warns on challenging telecom market conditions  Financial Times

Nokia has warned of a deterioration in the market for telecoms equipment this year in the wake of rival Ericsson’s shock warning last week. The Finnish company however issued a milder view of the market for its kit than Ericsson saying that it expects 2017 to be “slightly more challenging” than it had previously forecast. Ericsson warned that it expected the radio access network market to slump by a “high single digit” percentage but Nokia proved optimistic. Rajeev Suri, chief executive of Nokia, said: We expect our primary addressable market with communication service providers to be sligh...

item.title: Here's Miracle-Gro for Startups - Forbes Now
item.description:
Here's Miracle-Gro for Startups  Forbes Now

Fans of Xiaomi’s best-selling Mi5 smartphone in Spain last year. Credit: Chris Ratcliffe/Bloomberg Just as gardens need fertilizer, startups need nutrients to help them grow. A great product and a little market buzz may be enough to get a business off the ground. But sooner or later, most startups need a potent and sustainable fuel to really power their growth. That’s where patents come in. They’re Miracle-Gro for startups, an entrepreneur’s best friend. This is as true in China, a country that has been accused of stealing intellectual property, as it is in the U.S. Take Chinese startup Xia...

item.title: Chinese tech firm to take on leading global smartphone makers - RT
item.description:
Chinese tech firm to take on leading global smartphone makers  RT

Beijing-based electronics company Xiaomi says it's ready to challenge the world’s smartphone market dominated by Apple, Samsung and Huawei. Xiaomi has just become the fourth smartphone manufacturer to introduce its own self-designed processors as well as the first smartphone to be powered by a custom chipset. “The ability to create its own chipsets is the pinnacle achievement for any smartphone company,” said Lei Jun, Xiaomi’s CEO and co-founder at a launch event at the China National Convention Center in Beijing. The Surge S1 chipset was developed by the company’s subsidiary Pinecone forme...

item.title: Samsung promises ‘new beginning’ with Galaxy S8 launch - Financial Times
item.description:
Samsung promises ‘new beginning’ with Galaxy S8 launch  Financial Times

Samsung launched its new Galaxy S8 smartphone with a bombastic event in New York, promising a “new beginning” for mobile handset design as well as for the Korean company amid a series of corporate crises. The Galaxy S8’s signature feature is a new “infinity display” which wraps around the edges of the device to give a larger screen in a smaller body. Claiming the biggest design breakthrough since Apple’s iPhone set the template for touchscreen smartphones a decade ago, Samsung said the S8 and larger S8 Plus would mean less scrolling down a Facebook news feed and allow new kinds of multitask...
